title: Make decoration provider API public
Display installed dependencies

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body: The dependencies tab of an Add-on should display which ones I have installed already/give me a button to install a dependency individually.

title: Quick open support for opening a folder in the explorer
body:
WebStorm's quick open equivalent allows not only opening files, but also folders. In order to open a folder instead of a file, you either have to prefix the name with '/' or add it as a suffix.

For example you could use quick open (cmd + p) to enter something like:
* /node_modules/mocha
* test/

Once you open a folder, explorer panel is opened, it's scrolled to the selected folder and the folder is expanded.

It's super useful when working with huge projects and it's something I *really* miss in VSCode.

title: Inline color decorators mess up with pixel-sharp fonts
body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. --> 
<!-- Also please test using the latest insiders build to make sure your issue has not already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issue to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.25.0
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.04 LTS

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Keep "editor.colorDecorators" set to true
2. Use a pixel-perfect/pixel-sharp font like Monoid or Crisp
3. Open a file with color decorators
4. Notice the characters become misaligned a fraction of pixel (and then blurred) after the color decorator, ruining the whole purpose of the font
(Example pic magnified 400%: [Imgur](https://i.imgur.com/eoQmy4V.png))

Purposed solution: make the color decorators width always snap to an integer pixel value

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

title: Cannot uninstall VS Code on Windows Server 2016 using Settings App

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
Interesting use case here while using Visual Studio Code on a test server running Windows Server 2016. An exception is thrown when you attempt to uninstall via the settings app. Uninstall does work when using the Control Panel or when running the installer directly.

- VSCode Version: 1.26.0
- OS Version: Windows Server 2016 Standard

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Install VS Code on Windows Server 2016
2. Go to Settings -> System -> Apps & Features
3. Click Uninstall under VS Code

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4315558/43082512-3d314530-8e62-11e8-8199-1f15e6e9542c.png)

Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

title: Navigation trought parenthesis

title: Touch gestures (scrolling) don't work when Code is launched on machine without touchscreen
body:
Touch gestures (scrolling in code, solution explorer, …) don't work when Code is launched from a device without touchscreen. For example when you launch VSCode on a desktop without touchscreen and later RDP into such machine from a laptop with touchscreen the touch gestures don't work. 

When you open a new VSCode instance from within the RDP session (i.e. from touch-enabled device that is RDP'd into a device without touchscreen) the touch gestures work fine.

<!-- Use Help > Report Issue to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.24.1
- OS Version: WIN10 17134.167

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open VSCode on machine without touchscreen
2. RDP into that machine from a machine with a touchscreen
3. Attempt to scroll (code, …) using touch

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

title: Character keys not captured in shortcut combination "Ctrl+K,*"
body:

title: Automatic comment-block ending

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
Visual Studio Code lacks support for automatic comment-block ending in C and C++.

If you were to start a comment-block with `/*`, an automatic `*/` will not be added as it would be in the traditional Visual Studio. When I type `/*`, it should automatically be turned into `/**/` and the text cursor should be between the two `*`.

It isn't that big of a deal but it would be really nice to have this feature in Visual Studio Code.

title: Option to automatically open markdown in preview
body:
Add a setting `markdown.defaultView` to automatically open .md files in preview mode instead of editing mode.
This is so useful, because the most of time, I just want to read the .md files.

title: Better debug stop/restart support with compound launch configurations

milestone.title: On Deck
milestone.description:
The Issues assigned to the **On Deck** milestone under consideration for the upcoming milestones.
Our goal is to always have less than 100 Issues on deck.

body: In a compound launch configuration, Start Debugging (F5) starts all targets but Stop & Restart only affect the current target. This makes restarting all targets (e.g. after source code changes) very slow. Not sure the best way this could be improved but would like to Restart all targets with a single button/key. (NB I also made a comment here requesting post-launch task support for compound launch configurations: #2405).

title: Fix tasks spawned using wsl.exe

milestone.title: On Deck
milestone.description:
The Issues assigned to the **On Deck** milestone under consideration for the upcoming milestones.
Our goal is to always have less than 100 Issues on deck.

body:
The new wsl.exe has a different format from the older bash.exe in Windows.
```
> bash.exe -c "echo This works"
This works
> wsl.exe echo This works
This works
> wsl.exe "echo This does not work"
/bin/bash: echo This does not work: command not found
```
node-pty seems to quote all of the multi-word arguments passed to it, so tasks using wsl.exe are changed to pass in their array of arguments directly.

title: Support Autocomplete Brackets for String Interpolation
body:
This PR is to implement [54759](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/54749)

### Changes
* Added an attribute to autoClosingPairs hash called "onlyIn". It's an array that takes 3 values: "string", "comment", or "regex", and ensures that the autoClosingPair ONLY works within that scope. (Necessary for getting string interpolation to work).  
* Added another attribute to autoClosingPairs hash called "cursorPosition". Allows the user to input a position where they want the cursor to be moved to after autocomplete is done. The value must be within the range of 0 and close.length. Else, the cursor will default to the original behavior (cursor located just before the "close" string). This helps to move the cursor inside the brackets after the brackets are autocompleted for interpolation.
* Added definitions and functions to other files to ensure that the above attributes are accessible/usable.
* Added tests to test the above implementations.

title: VS Code in portable mode cannot load loc UI first time after the move

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
- VSCode Version: 1.25
- OS Version: Windows 10

**Customer feedback:**
[Feedback from Yuchen Deng in Marketplace](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=MS-CEINTL.vscode-language-pack-zh-hans&tracking_data=eyJTb3VyY2UiOiJFbWFpbCIsIlR5cGUiOiJOb3RpZmljYXRpb24iLCJTSUQiOiJtcy5HYWxsZXJ5Tm90aWZpY2F0aW9ucy5yZXZpZXctdXBkYXRlZC1zdWJzY3JpcHRpb24iLCJTVHlwZSI6IkNPTiIsIlJlY2lwIjozLCJFbGVtZW50IjoiaGVyby9jdGEifQ%3D%3D#review-details)

**Translation of the feedback:**
If VS Code uses Portable mode (the directory has the data sub-directory), and has installed the language pack, if moved to another path, it shows English UI the first time to VS Code. I assume it is because the language pack is based on absolute path to find translations, Rather than a relative path.

milestone.title: Backlog

body:
Previously the centered layout in zen mode had a fixed width, meaning that if you resize the window the centered section will remain the same as long as it still fits in the resized window. The behaviour now is for the centered section width to be proportional to the size of the window. See below:

title: [folding] Add keyboard shortcut to jump between #region and #endregion

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
How difficult would it be to add a keyboard shortcut to jump between `#region` and `#endregion`, the same way you can jump between opening and closing brackets `[]`, braces `{}`, and parentheses `()`? I would prefer the same keyboard shortcut, so just adding this to `editor.action.jumpToBracket` would be perfect. However, I can imagine that some might prefer it to be a separate command, or it may be better to do that from an implementation standpoint.

I apologize if I'm missing an existing shortcut, but I couldn't find anything in the current keybindings.

title: Allow to specify files to ignore for HTML and other formatters
body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

I use the HTML formatter in VSC by enabling `editor.formatOnSave`. However, there are some files, including HTML ones, that I want to NOT format on save. Therefore, please allow us to specify an ignore file, using a format similar to `.gitignore`, to not format on save, when this file exists in a project's root dir. 

Thanks!

title: Rectangle commands for large file editing
body:
### Problem
It is difficult to modify large files (more than 10k lines) efficiently, as we are limited in cursors, as showed in the following gif.

![Cursor](https://i.imgur.com/fc78CRp.gif)

While i do understand the possible problem to have more than 10k active cursors at the same time, i still think it would be nice to be able to edit large file.

### Solution and request 
I think emacs has a interesting solution for file editing without using multiple cursors: the [rectangle commands](https://www.gnu.org/software/emacs/manual/html_node/emacs/Rectangles.html).
Maybe using this "marking" solution could enable vscode to modify larger file.
Thanks.

title: Broken ${workspaceFolder} for multi-root workspaces.

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
When operating under a multi-root workspaces, files not created within vscode receive incorrect path from ${workspaceFolder}. Instead of receiving the top-most folder relative to the file's hierarchy, it always gets the top project's root path. The correct path is returned on files created by vscode.

- VSCode Version: 1.25.1
- OS Version: Debian 9.5 Stretch

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open multi-root workspace
2. Define task with following command: `echo ${workspaceFolder}`
3. Navigate to source directory of folder not in topmost root folder -> `vi ./test` -> :wq 
4. Open the test file and run the command defined in step 2. Note that the topmost root-directory is returned instead of the file's root directory. 

Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

title: Enhancement: finer control of word separators
body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

Currently, the setting term `"editor.wordSeparators"` only tells the editor to separate words *at* these characters. Can we make it *before* or *after* the separators?

Now I take LaTeX as an example. If we remove `\` from "editor.wordSeparators", then double click on `\cmdA\cmdB\cmdC`, we will select the whole expression. However, as the expression is actually three commands, we should select a single (e.g. `\cmdA`) one at a time. That means, we should only separate words *before* `\`, not after.

title: Add support for themable window border
body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
On Windows 10 at least with the new custom titlebar (`"window.titleBarStyle": "custom"`) vscode loses its window border. It would be great for a theme to be able to specify a border color in this case (if desired). Because with some themes (particularly mine) it can be hard to tell where 1 window ends and another one starts.

I tried setting `titleBar.border` but it wasn't what I was looking for:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/641685/42843782-129a8ef8-89df-11e8-9f00-3b23d151af1a.png)

//cc @sbatten

title: Improve readability of diagnotic hovers

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
The number one annoyance I have and hear from people about VS Code + TypeScript is that type errors are hard to read. TypeScript will display nested type errors with each level indented, but because of the line wrapping, that indentation basically lost.
This makes the error hard to follow and in consequence hard to solve.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10532611/42839855-dbc732a2-89b9-11e8-841d-f0b66f3a62fb.png)

Here are things that I think would improve the readability:
- Add an option to enable horizontal scrolling in hovers. This would mean the indentation would actually have the intended visual effect.
- Make the width of the hover configurable. I have way more space on my screen it could utilize.
- Add smart wrapping that preserves indentation.
- Add markdown support to diagnostics and make TypeScript output markdown. This would mean not the whole diagnostic has to be rendered in a monospace font, therefor saving horizontal space. The parts that are code would use backticks instead of single quotes.
